Tuscan Bean and Kale Soup

Jan 17, 2019 • Brittany

I know, I know. Kale, ew right? WRONG. This soup combines the creaminess of cannellini beans with the bulk of tender kale and cabbage, all blended together in a rich tomato broth with plenty of olive oil and parmesan cheese. When I first saw this recipe I thought it wouldn't be one I would ever make, I'm not a huge fan of pasta fagioli soup and this seemed to be in the same boat.

That being said, the book where this recipe originated (Salt, Fat, Acid, Heat: Mastering the Elements of Good Cooking) has really rocked my world! Forget the Netflix show, this is a cook book you can sit down and read. That's right, READ. There's so much more to this cookbook than just recipes. The author, Samin Nosrat, takes the time to go over so many basic cooking techniques and how to bring them all together time and time again for food that is absolutely delicious. And this soup is the perfect embodiment of that! So without further ado, I present:





Tuscan Bean and Kale Soup

Ingredients:
Extra Virgin Olive Oil (use a high quality olive oil, note that it is not the light variety!)
Optional 2 oz pancetta or bacon, diced (not really optional it adds a great meatiness)
1 medium yellow onion, diced (about 1 1/2 c.)
2 celery stalks, diced (about 2/3c.)
2 medium carrots, peeled and diced (1c)
2 bay leaves
Salt
Freshly ground pepper
2 garlic cloves, thinly sliced
2 c. crushed canned or fresh tomatoes in their juice (I recommend a large can of whole, peeled)
3 c. cooked beans, such as cannellini, corona, or cranberry, cooking liquid reserved
             (from about 1 c. raw; canned beans can be used)*
1 oz freshly grated parmesan (about 1/3 c.), rind reserved
3-4 c. chicken stock or water
2 bunches kale, thinly sliced (about 6c. sliced)**
1/2 small head green or savoy cabbage, core removed and thinly sliced (about 3 c. sliced)

Directions:
Set a large Dutch oven or stockpot over medium-high heat and add 1 T. olive oil. When the oil shimmers, add the pancetta or bacon, if using, and cook, stirring for 1 min, until it just begins to brown.

Add the onion, celery, carrots and bay leaves. Season generously with salt and pepper. Reduce heat to medium and cook, stirring occasionally until the vegetables are tender and just starting to brown, about 15 minutes. Dig a small hole in the center of the pot, then add another tablespoon of olive oil. Add the garlic and let it sizzle gently until it gives off an aroma, about 30 seconds. Before the garlic has a chance to brown, add the tomatoes. Stir, taste, and add salt as needed.

Let the tomatoes simmer until they cook down to a jammy consistency, about 8 minutes***, then add the beans and their cooking liquid, half the grated parmesan and its rind and enough stock to cover. Add two immoderate splashes of olive oil, about 1/4 cup. Stirring occasionally, bring the soup back to a simmer. Add the kale and cabbage and bring to a simmer again, adding more stock or water as needed to cover.

Cook until the flavors have come together and the greens are tender, about 20 minutes more. Taste and adjust for salt. If you want the soup to be thinner, add more stock as desired. Remove the parmesan rind and the bay leaves.

Serve with a drizzle of your best olive oil and grated parmesan.



Some notes:
* I couldn't find dried cannellini beans so I used 2 cans. They were delicious, but I highly recommend if you have time to soak and cook your own beans a day in advance. You won't be sorry!
**I bought a 1lb bag of prewashed, precut kale. I used about half of it instead of cleaning and slicing my own kale. All of the massive bitter stems were already removed and the kale was clean and bite sized.
*** I cooked down the tomatoes much longer than recommended. I thought 8 minutes didn't quite get a jammy consistency and since I had the time I cooked it probably closer to 20.

You could always use this soup as a base for pasta fagioli if you wanted. It would also work as a great freezer staple, just freeze prior to adding the greens and once thawed complete the recipe as directed.

Here is a link to the cookbook this recipe came from, I know I will be added it to my cookbook repertoire soon:  https://www.saltfatacidheat.com/ 



Until next time, happy eating!
